I.N.S.P.I.R.E.
Aligned Pedagogical Frameworks For Transformational Learning
Prompt Techniques to Help You Think Yourself
It‚Äôs been our experience that most people fail to achieve good results with LLMs because they don't understand how they work. If you want to use LLMs effectively, you must comprehend the concept of traveling through vector spaces. Once you grasp this idea, you'll be able to learn things that you didn't even know you needed to learn. And then, you will be able to perform tasks you didn't know you needed to do.

Over hundreds of hours of GPT use since last December, we‚Äôve built this intuition. Now we‚Äôre sharing it with a series of practical methods to support others in getting better results while developing their deep understanding of what‚Äôs special about LLMs and how to get good results. This is how you learn prompting. 

We call this LLM framework and techniques S.C.R.I.B.E.R (Seek, Critique, Reflect, Inquire, Broaden/contract, Explain, Recurse) and we can teach you and your team how to get excellent results from LLMs while building their capacity and identifying their unique contributions.

Let‚Äôs ease in with a simplified explanation as if you were five years old. 

S.C.R.I.B.E.R Like You‚Äôre Five
Prompt Techniques to Help You Think Yourself
Set Sail on an Adventure with Your Navigator's Talking Map!
Welcome to a world of discovery and imagination! On this journey, you're not just wandering; you're an intrepid navigator with an extraordinary companion ‚Äì a talking map. This map is no ordinary paper; it's alive with knowledge and adventure!
Your Interactive Guide: The talking map knows about every nook and cranny of the world. It doesn't just show you places; it talks about them, suggests where to explore, and helps you think of questions about unknown corners of the world.
Journey Across the Map: As you travel with your map, it might say, "Have you ever wondered what lies beyond that mountain range?" even when you don‚Äôt know there is a mountain range, because it has a maps eye view :D or "Let's explore what's inside the belly of a fish at the bottom of the ocean!" It's always ready to take you to new places and open up worlds you have yet to think to discover.
The Power of Curiosity: Your map's magic lies in its ability to spark your curiosity. Every new place it points out and every question it suggests is like unlocking a hidden treasure of knowledge. It encourages you to think, explore, and learn about things far beyond the ordinary.
Navigating the Unknown: Remember, with your talking map, you're the navigator of your adventure. It's there to guide you, show you hidden paths, and inspire you to ask questions and find answers.
Ready to Discover Hidden Treasures? So, grab your navigator's talking map, and let's embark on a journey of discovery and learning. Who knows what wonders we'll uncover together!
Embark on an Epic Quest with Your Map of Everything!
Welcome to a world brimming with endless possibilities! Imagine you're starting a grand adventure with two special maps in your hands. The first is your "map of something" ‚Äì it's a map of what you already know, like your neighborhood, your favorite park, or the subjects you've learned in school. The second is a truly magical map, the "map of everything," and it knows every secret and wonder in the world.
Your Map and the Map of Everything: Your map might show where you live, where your school is, or where you've been on vacation. It's familiar and comfortable. But the "map of everything" is different. It's like a guide that knows all the places you've never seen or even imagined. When you tell this map about the places on your personal map, it starts to create paths to new, incredible destinations.
Journey Beyond the Known: Think of your "map of everything" as a magical companion. Once you share with it where you are on your "map of something," it begins to light up paths to extraordinary places. It could reveal a path from your backyard to a jungle full of talking animals, or from your classroom to a castle in the clouds!
Discovering New Worlds Together: Your "map of everything" doesn't just take you to new places; it also asks you questions and suggests adventures. It might ask, "Do you want to see where the dinosaurs lived?" or suggest, "Let's find out what's at the edge of the universe!" With every question and suggestion, it helps you explore worlds beyond your wildest dreams.
Your Adventure Awaits: With these two maps, you're not just an explorer ‚Äì you're a master navigator of knowledge and imagination. The "map of everything" guides you to the unknown, to help you discover and learn about amazing things you've never even thought about.
Are You Ready to Explore the Unknown? Grab your "map of something" and join hands with your "map of everything." Let's set off on a journey of endless discovery, where each step takes you to a new world of wonder and excitement!



S.C.R.I.B.E.R For Adults
Prompt Techniques to Help You Think for Yourself
Introduction
Artificial intelligence is changing the world of work. Some people are getting great results, and some find LLMs, like chatGPT, fun yet useless for ‚Äúthe real world of work.‚Äù The opportunity is there, yet it requires us to learn how LLMs work, and from there, we will be able to get better results.
In a nutshell, LLMs store knowledge in a graph representing ideas in space. By speaking to it, you move around in this graph. Once you‚Äôre somewhere in the graph, you can ask it what is around you that you ‚Äúcan‚Äôt see.‚Äù 
This framework will allow you to use chatGPT and other LLMs to help you think, not think for you. We developed these principles to help you experience this intuition about how LLMs operate and to teach you that you can now, perhaps for the first time in history, teach yourself the things you don‚Äôt even know you don‚Äôt know.
May you wield this tool well and create great benefits for yourself, your communities, and the world.
The S.C.R.I.B.E.R Framework for Prompting
Seek: Exploring your gaps in different domains of knowledge.
Critique: Actively seek constructive critique from antagonist personas.
Reflect: Procedurally review the LLM‚Äôs work and create tools to think with.
Inquire: Ask the AI to ask you questions to help it navigate to new spaces.
Broaden/Contract: Seek gaps. Ask the LLM for non-overlapping options and pick.
Explain: Ask LLM to share its reasoning for transparency and corrections.
Recurse: Ask the LLM to ask it to ask you to ask it.

The following table shares the SCRIBE Framework in three parts.
Principles are ideas that you keep it in mind and attempt to act upon them.
Techniques are how you can apply the principles. It‚Äôs just one method of many.
The Way of Being is a quality of presence from which the principles and techniques can emerge. It can be cultivated by repeated practice of the techniques and deep reflection on the principles. It is what matters in the end.

Note: Do NOT memorize this list. 
These techniques and principles are tools to help us embody the knowledge. Aim to have a mindset of using LLMs as a tool for thought. 
Experts don't recite steps; they embody their knowledge. Imagine a chef constantly looking up recipes! It's not about following a checklist; it's about making the knowledge a part of who you are. It‚Äôs from here that new principles and techniques will emerge. 
The ultimate goal of learning is to become.

Here are 3 questions to help prepare the presentation for the 16 year old homeschool student:

1. What is the student's current level of familiarity with AI and large language models like ChatGPT? This will help determine how much background information to include.

2. What are the student's primary learning goals and areas of interest? Tailoring examples and activities to their interests will help engage them.

3. What format would work best for the student - a slide deck, a written guide, video lessons, or a combination? Knowing their preferred learning style will make the content more effective.

Here is a detailed outline for the presentation:

Title Slide: 
"Becoming an AI Navigator: Exploring and Learning with Language Models"
- Include an image of a compass, map, or explorer

Slide 1: What are AI Language Models?
- Define AI and language models in simple terms
- Explain how they are trained on huge amounts of text data
- Use the analogy of a vast map of knowledge 
- Include a diagram illustrating a neural network

Slide 2: Interacting with AI - Speaking the Language
- Explain that we "navigate" the AI's knowledge map by conversing with it
- Describe how the AI uses the concepts in a prompt to locate relevant information 
- Suggest thinking of prompts as "directions" to steer the AI to the knowledge you seek
- Show examples of simple and more advanced prompts

Slide 3: The SCRIBER Framework for Prompting
- Introduce SCRIBER as a set of techniques for getting the most out of AI
- List out the components: Seek, Critique, Reflect, Inquire, Broaden/Contract, Explain, Recurse
- Use icons or emojis to represent each element
- Emphasize it as a toolkit, not a rigid checklist

Slides 4-10: Dive into each SCRIBER element with examples
- Seek: Demo prompts for exploring new topics and seeking expert perspectives
- Critique: Show how to ask the AI for constructive feedback 
- Reflect: Provide fill-in-the-blank templates for reflection exercises
- Inquire: Highlight using the AI to generate probing questions
- Broaden/Contract: Demo prompts for brainstorming diverse ideas and focusing in
- Explain: Example of asking the AI to break down its reasoning step-by-step
- Recurse: Illustrate a recursive prompt-response chain 

Slide 11: Becoming an Independent Learner
- Frame SCRIBER as a set of learning strategies, not just AI techniques  
- Discuss how these skills support curiosity, critical thinking and self-directed learning
- Encourage reflecting on one's own thought processes
- Include a aspirational photo of an explorer, scientist or philosopher

Slide 12: Your AI Learning Journey 
- Prompt the student to reflect on what they want to explore with AI tools
- Provide ideas for fun starter projects in different domains
- Include links to recommended resources for learning more
- End with an inspiring quote about the joys of lifelong learning

I recommend a slide deck as the primary format, with a supplemental written guide detailing the prompts and techniques. Consider recording a walkthrough video for students who prefer multimedia formats. Be sure to include eye-catching visuals, diagrams, and emojis to make the slides engaging and memorable. Let me know if you would like me to elaborate on any part of the outline!

Title Slide:
"Becoming an AI Explorer: Discovering New Worlds of Knowledge"
- Background image: A vibrant illustration of a young explorer setting off on a journey, with a robot companion representing the AI
- Include a brief subtitle emphasizing the interactive, self-directed nature of the learning process

Slide 1: Embarking on an AI Adventure!
- Hook the student with an exciting scenario: "Imagine you had a brilliant robot partner who could help you learn about anything you wanted to explore. That's what AI language models can do!"
- Provide a high-level overview of what AI language models are and how they can be used for learning
- Use a simple analogy: "It's like having a super-smart friend who has read every book in the library and can discuss any topic with you."
- Include an engaging cartoon or illustration of a robot and a student having a conversation

Slide 2: Cracking the Code: How AI Language Models Work
- Explain the basic concepts of machine learning and natural language processing in simple terms
- Compare language models to the student's existing knowledge: "Just like how you learned to speak by listening to people talk, language models learn by studying huge amounts of text data."
- Use a diagram to show how the AI processes and generates text based on patterns it has learned
- Emphasize that interacting with the AI is like having a conversation - the better you are at asking questions, the more you'll learn!

Slide 3: Navigating the AI's World of Knowledge
- Introduce the concept of the AI's "knowledge map" - the vast network of information it has learned
- Explain that we navigate this map by giving the AI directions in the form of prompts
- Use a metaphor of a choose-your-own-adventure book: "Each prompt is like choosing which page to turn to. The AI will take you to new places based on what you ask."
- Include a colorful mind map graphic showing different topics and how they connect

Slide 4: The Magic Words: Crafting Powerful Prompts
- Explain that prompts are the key to unlocking the AI's knowledge
- Provide examples of effective prompts for learning, such as:
  - "Explain [topic] to me like I'm a 10-year-old."
  - "What are the most important things to know about [subject]?"
  - "How does [concept A] relate to [concept B]?"
- Encourage the student to start brainstorming prompts for topics they're curious about
- Include fill-in-the-blank templates to help them structure their prompts

Slide 5: Introducing the SCRIBER Framework 
- Frame SCRIBER as a toolkit for "leveling up" their AI exploration skills
- Present each component (Seek, Critique, Reflect, Inquire, Broaden/Contract, Explain, Recurse) with a brief, one-sentence explanation
- Use memorable icons or characters to represent each element (e.g. a magnifying glass for "Seek," a question mark for "Inquire")
- Emphasize that these techniques will help them learn more effectively and independently
- Include an illustration of the components as tools in an explorer's backpack

Slides 6-12: Mastering the SCRIBER Techniques
- Dedicate one slide to each component of the framework 
- Provide 2-3 example prompts or activities for each one, tailored to common school subjects
  - E.g. for "Reflect," show a template for summarizing what they learned about a history topic
  - For "Broaden/Contract," demo how to generate ideas for a creative writing assignment
- Include colorful visuals, emojis, and characters to make each slide fun and engaging
- Encourage the student to jot down ideas for how they could use each technique in their own learning

Slide 13: Planning Your AI Learning Quest
- Invite the student to brainstorm a list of topics or skills they want to explore using AI
- Provide a fill-in-the-blank quest map where they can plan out their learning journey
- Include space for them to write down their goals, questions, and ideas
- Encourage them to share their quest map with a parent, tutor, or study buddy who can support their learning
- Include an inspiring quote about the power of curiosity and self-directed learning

Slide 14: Resources for Your AI Adventurer's Toolkit
- Provide links to beginner-friendly AI platforms and resources (e.g. ChatGPT, AI Dungeon, educational videos)
- Recommend books, websites, or podcasts that explore AI and its applications in an engaging way
- Include a glossary of key terms and concepts covered in the presentation
- Encourage the student to connect with other AI enthusiasts through online communities or local clubs
- End with a motivational message about embracing lifelong learning and the exciting possibilities of AI

The written guide would follow a similar structure, with each section providing more detailed explanations, examples, and step-by-step instructions for using the SCRIBER techniques. It can also include printable worksheets, writing prompts, and reflection exercises to reinforce the learning. 

The key is to present AI as an exciting, accessible tool for exploring their interests and enhancing their learning. By grounding abstract concepts in relatable analogies, providing clear examples, and encouraging hands-on experimentation, we can empower the student to take control of their learning journey and discover new worlds of knowledge with their AI companion by their side.

SCRIBER

- Provides a clear, step-by-step approach to prompting
- Encourages critical thinking and self-reflection
- Emphasizes the importance of seeking diverse perspectives
	
- May be too technical or complex for some learners
- Primarily focused on AI interaction rather than general learning strategies
- Requires a basic understanding of AI concepts to fully grasp
INSPIRE	
- Grounded in established learning theories and pedagogical principles
- Emphasizes a holistic approach to learning and personal growth
- Encourages active, experiential learning and problem-solving
- Promotes collaboration and interactive learning experiences
	
- Less focused on the specific techniques for interacting with AI
- Some elements may be more challenging to implement in a homeschool setting
- Requires a broader understanding of learning theories and assessment methods

2. Draw upon the pedagogical principles and learning theories from INSPIRE to create a holistic, engaging learning experience
3. Emphasize self-directed, inquiry-based learning, with AI as a supportive tool for exploration and discovery
4. Provide a balance of independent AI interaction and collaborative, interactive learning activities
5. Include reflective exercises and self-assessment tools to help students track their progress and growth
6. Offer guidance for parents and tutors on how to support and assess AI-assisted learning in a homeschool setting

By combining the AI-specific techniques of SCRIBER with the proven educational strategies of INSPIRE, we can create a powerful, flexible framework that empowers students to take control of their learning journey and harness the potential of AI for intellectual growth and discovery.

- Ability to formulate clear, focused questions and prompts
- Critical thinking and information literacy skills
- Reflective and metacognitive practices
- Collaborative and communication skills

- Seek: Encouraging curiosity and exploration
- Critique: Fostering critical thinking and information literacy
- Reflect: Promoting reflective and metacognitive practices
INSPIRE:
- Inquiry-Based Learning: Supporting self-directed, question-driven learning

- Resilience & Grit: Building perseverance and problem-solving skills

- Generate "what if" scenarios
- Explore interconnections between topics	- AI-assisted research projects
- Virtual field trips and simulations	- Concept maps and knowledge networks
- Reflective journals and portfolios	- Encourage questioning and exploration
- Provide guidance on evaluating information quality
Critical Thinking and Information Literacy	Students use AI to analyze and evaluate information, consider multiple perspectives	- Critique arguments and evidence 
- Seek diverse viewpoints
- Fact-check and verify claims	- AI-assisted debate and argumentation
- Comparative analysis of sources	- Rubrics for evaluating reasoning and evidence
- Self- and peer-assessment of critical thinking skills	- Model critical thinking strategies
- Facilitate discussions on information bias and reliability

- Generate self-assessment questions

- Metacognitive strategy tutorials	- Reflective writing prompts and exercises
- Self-assessment checklists and inventories	- Encourage regular reflection and self-assessment

- Facilitate inquiry-based discussions and debriefs

- Peer feedback and assessment	- Foster a culture of collaboration and knowledge sharing
- Moderate and guide collaborative AI interactions

- Generate strategies for overcoming obstacles
- Reflect on failures and successes	- AI-assisted goal-setting and planning
- Personalized learning path simulations	- Growth mindset self-assessment scales
- Resilience and grit inventories	- Model and reinforce growth mindset language and behaviors
- Provide support and encouragement throughout learning journey

By integrating key elements from SCRIBER and INSPIRE, along with specific AI techniques, learning activities, assessment methods, and guidance for teachers and parents, this framework empowers students to become curious, critical, and self-directed learners who can thrive in an AI-enhanced educational landscape.

I.N.S.P.I.R.E.
Aligned Pedagogical Frameworks For Transformational Learning
Prompt Techniques to Help You Think Yourself
It‚Äôs been our experience that most people fail to achieve good results with LLMs because they don't
understand how they work. If you want to use LLMs effectively, you must comprehend the concept
of traveling through vector spaces. Once you grasp this idea, you'll be able to learn things that you
didn't even know you needed to learn. And then, you will be able to perform tasks you didn't know
you needed to do.
Over hundreds of hours of GPT use since last December, we‚Äôve built this intuition. Now we‚Äôre
sharing it with a series of practical methods to support others in getting better results while
developing their deep understanding of what‚Äôs special about LLMs and how to get good results.
This is how you learn prompting.
We call this LLM framework and techniques S.C.R.I.B.E.R (Seek, Critique, Reflect, Inquire,
Broaden/contract, Explain, Recurse) and we can teach you and your team how to get excellent
results from LLMs while building their capacity and identifying their unique contributions.
Let‚Äôs ease in with a simplified explanation as if you were five years old.
S.C.R.I.B.E.R Like You‚Äôre Five
Prompt Techniques to Help You Think Yourself
‚óè 
Set Sail on an Adventure with Your Navigator's Talking Map!

yet it requires us to learn how LLMs work, and from there, we will be able to get better results.

move around in this graph. Once you‚Äôre somewhere in the graph, you can ask it what is around you
that you ‚Äúcan‚Äôt see.‚Äù
This framework will allow you to use chatGPT and other LLMs to help you think, not think for you.
We developed these principles to help you experience this intuition about how LLMs operate and to
teach you that you can now, perhaps for the first time in history, teach yourself the things you don‚Äôt

Principles are ideas that you keep it in mind and attempt to act upon them.

the principles. It is what matters in the end.

These techniques and principles are tools to help us embody the knowledge. Aim to have a

It‚Äôs from here that new principles and techniques will emerge.

messages.content:
Table 1: INSPIRE Framework with Example Prompts

Framework Element	Description	Example Prompt
Inquiry-Based Learning	Learners actively ask questions, investigate, and research.	"What are the key questions we should be asking about [topic]? How might we design an experiment to investigate [hypothesis]?"
Narrative & Reflective Learning	Emphasizes storytelling and personal reflection.	"Reflect on a time when you faced a similar challenge. What lessons from that experience could be applied here? Write a short narrative exploring your thoughts."
Self-Directed Learning	Learners set and pursue their own learning goals.	"What do you want to learn about [subject]? Set three learning goals for yourself and create a plan to achieve them."
Problem-Based Learning	Learning through addressing real-world problems.	"Analyze the problem of [real-world issue]. What are the root causes, and what potential solutions could be implemented?"
Interactive & Collaborative Learning	Learning through interaction and collaboration.	"Work with your team to create a shared vision for [project]. What are each member's strengths, and how can you leverage them for success?"
Resilience & Grit	Developing persistence and resilience.	"Reflect on a time when you faced a setback or failure. What strategies did you use to overcome it and persist towards your goal?"
Experiential Learning	Hands-on activities and experiential learning.	"Apply the concepts of [theory] to a real-world scenario. What insights can you gain from this hands-on experience?"
Self-Efficacy / Entrepreneurial Self-Efficacy	Confidence in entrepreneurial capabilities.	"Identify a business opportunity you're passionate about. What skills and resources would you need to pursue it successfully?"

Table 2: SCRIBER Framework with Example Prompts

Framework Element	Description	Example Prompt
Seek	Exploring gaps in different domains of knowledge.	"Pretend you're an expert in [field]. What key concepts would someone need to understand to have a strong foundation in this area?"
Critique	Actively seek constructive critique from antagonist personas.	"Imagine you're a tough critic reviewing this [work]. What constructive feedback would you give to help improve its quality and impact?"
Reflect	Procedurally review the LLM's work and create tools to think with.	"Analyze the structure and reasoning behind the LLM's response. What insights can you draw from its approach? Create a mind map to visualize the key concepts."
Inquire	Ask the AI to ask you questions to help it navigate to new spaces.	"If you were an AI trying to understand [topic], what questions would you ask a human expert to gain deeper insights?"
Broaden/Contract	Seek gaps. Ask the LLM for non-overlapping options and pick.	"Generate three diverse, contrasting approaches to solving [problem]. Analyze the strengths and weaknesses of each, and select the most promising one."
Explain	Ask LLM to share its reasoning for transparency and corrections.	"Walk through your step-by-step reasoning behind this recommendation. What principles and assumptions are you basing it on?"
Recurse	Ask the LLM to ask it to ask you to ask it.	"Imagine you're a consultant helping a client with [issue]. What questions would you ask them to better understand their needs and goals?"

Critique:
The SCRIBER framework prompts seem more memorable and actionable, as they focus on specific techniques for interacting with LLMs to enhance learning and problem-solving. The INSPIRE prompts, while grounded in learning theory, feel more general and less directly tied to working with AI.

However, the INSPIRE framework covers a broader range of learning approaches and skills, from self-reflection to entrepreneurship. It feels more comprehensive in scope, while SCRIBER is more narrowly focused on prompting techniques.

Questions for developing a synergistic approach:
1. How might we combine the best elements of both frameworks to create a holistic approach to AI-assisted learning?
2. What additional elements or techniques could we incorporate to make the framework even more effective and engaging?
3. How can we structure the framework to be both comprehensive and easy to remember and apply?

New Synergistic Framework: DISCOVER

Framework Element	Description	Example Prompt
Dive Deep	Explore a topic in depth from multiple angles, seeking expert perspectives.	"If you were writing a comprehensive guide on [topic] for beginners, what key concepts, examples, and resources would you include?"
Inquire & Investigate	Ask probing questions and design experiments to test ideas and hypotheses.	"What are the most pressing unanswered questions in [field]? How could we design a thought experiment or study to investigate one of them?"
Synthesize & Strategize	Combine insights from diverse sources to develop creative solutions and action plans.	"Analyze the key takeaways from [sources] on [problem]. What common themes emerge, and how could we synthesize them into a novel approach?"
Critique & Correct	Seek out constructive criticism and use it to refine your thinking and iterate on ideas.	"Play the role of a skeptical audience member. What questions or objections might they raise about this [idea/product/argument]? How could we address them?"
Open-Ended Exploration	Follow your curiosity down unexpected paths and make serendipitous discoveries.	"What are some surprising connections between [topic 1] and [topic 2]? Explore how insights from one domain could be applied to the other."
Reflect & Refine	Regularly step back to examine your learning process and identify areas for improvement.	"Review your recent projects and identify patterns in your strengths and weaknesses. What skills do you want to develop further, and what habits could support that growth?"
Engage & Experiment	Seek out hands-on, immersive learning experiences to test and apply knowledge.	"Design a small-scale experiment or prototype to test [concept] in a real-world setting. What insights can you gain from this hands-on experience?"
Realize & Reinforce	Celebrate progress and achievements, and use them to build confidence and momentum.	"Reflect on a recent success or milestone in your learning journey. What strategies and mindsets contributed to this achievement, and how can you build on them going forward?"

The DISCOVER framework aims to combine the best elements of INSPIRE and SCRIBER, while adding new elements to create a comprehensive and memorable approach to AI-assisted learning. It incorporates inquiry, reflection, experimentation, and strategic thinking, while emphasizing the importance of both depth and breadth in exploration. The example prompts are designed to be engaging and actionable, guiding learners through the process of discovery and growth. By following the DISCOVER framework, learners can harness the power of AI to deepen their understanding, expand their skills, and unlock new possibilities for personal and professional growth.

You raise an excellent point about the importance of understanding embeddings and leveraging the AI's ability to explore nearby knowledge spaces. The DISCOVER framework could definitely be enhanced by explicitly incorporating these key concepts. Let's revisit the framework with these ideas in mind:

New Synergistic Framework: EXPLORER

Framework Element	Description	Example Prompt
Embark on Embedding Expeditions	Use the LLM to navigate to different embedding spaces and uncover hidden knowledge.	"Based on what we've discussed about [topic], what are 10 related but distinct concepts or questions that I should explore to deepen my understanding?"
Xplore Nearby Neighborhoods	Ask the AI to identify clusters of related ideas and generate novel insights and questions.	"Analyze the main ideas we've covered so far. What are some adjacent or tangentially related topics that could offer surprising insights or applications?"
Personas as Guides	Engage with the LLM as different personas to gain new perspectives and ideas.	"Imagine you're an expert in [field] with a contrarian view on [topic]. What alternative theories or approaches would you propose, and why?"
Leverage Divergence & Convergence	Repeatedly broaden and narrow your focus to explore ideas from multiple angles.	"Generate 5 wildly different potential solutions to [problem]. Now, identify the most promising elements from each and combine them into a single, refined approach."

Title: Developing an Adaptive Framework for Self-Directed Learning using AI-Assisted Scaffolding

Abstract:
This research project investigates the design and implementation of an adaptive learning framework that leverages AI-assisted scaffolding to support self-directed learning and enhance learners' self-efficacy. The framework, called INSPIRE-AI (Inquiry-based, Narrative-driven, Self-directed, Personalized, Interactive, Reflective, and Engaging AI-assisted Learning), integrates key elements from the INSPIRE pedagogy, such as inquiry-based learning, narrative and reflective learning, and self-efficacy development, with AI-powered tools and techniques to create a personalized, engaging learning experience.

The study employs a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative data from learning analytics and assessments with qualitative data from learner interviews and reflective journals. The research aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the INSPIRE-AI framework in promoting self-directed learning, increasing learner engagement, and improving learning outcomes across various domains.

The findings suggest that the INSPIRE-AI framework successfully supports learners in developing the skills and mindsets necessary for self-directed learning, such as curiosity, critical thinking, and resilience. Learners reported increased confidence in their ability to navigate complex topics, identify knowledge gaps, and seek out relevant resources. The AI-assisted scaffolding provided personalized guidance and feedback, adapting to learners' individual needs and preferences.

The study concludes that the INSPIRE-AI framework offers a promising approach to fostering self-directed learning in the era of AI-enhanced education. By leveraging the strengths of both human-centered pedagogy and AI-powered tools, the framework empowers learners to take control of their learning journey, develop a growth mindset, and cultivate a lifelong love for learning. The research highlights the potential for AI to serve as a powerful ally in supporting learners' autonomy, engagement, and self-efficacy.

Future research should explore the long-term impact of the INSPIRE-AI framework on learners' academic and personal growth, as well as its applicability across different educational contexts and demographic groups. Additionally, further investigation into the ethical implications of AI-assisted learning and the role of educators in facilitating these experiences is warranted.

Conclusion:
The INSPIRE-AI framework represents a significant step forward in the design of adaptive, AI-enhanced learning experiences that prioritize learner autonomy, engagement, and self-efficacy. By synergistically combining the principles of the INSPIRE pedagogy with the capabilities of AI-powered tools, the framework offers a roadmap for creating learning environments that empower learners to take control of their own learning journey and develop the skills and mindsets necessary for lifelong learning.

The research demonstrates the potential for AI to serve as a powerful ally in supporting self-directed learning, providing personalized guidance, feedback, and resources tailored to each learner's unique needs and preferences. The INSPIRE-AI framework successfully promotes the development of key skills and dispositions, such as curiosity, critical thinking, resilience, and a growth mindset, which are essential for navigating the complexities of the 21st-century knowledge landscape.

As AI continues to transform the educational landscape, it is crucial that we develop frameworks and approaches that center on learners' needs, aspirations, and well-being. The INSPIRE-AI framework offers a promising model for leveraging the strengths of both human-centered pedagogy and AI-powered tools to create learning experiences that are engaging, empowering, and transformative.

Future research should build upon the findings of this study, exploring the long-term impact of the INSPIRE-AI framework on learners' academic and personal growth, as well as its potential applications across diverse educational contexts and populations. Additionally, ongoing dialogue and collaboration among educators, researchers, and AI developers are essential to ensure that AI-enhanced learning experiences are designed and implemented in an ethical, equitable, and learner-centered manner.

In conclusion, the INSPIRE-AI framework represents a significant contribution to the field of AI-enhanced education, offering a roadmap for creating adaptive, engaging, and empowering learning experiences that foster self-directed learning, cultivate a growth mindset, and prepare learners for the challenges and opportunities of the 21st century.

   - Log relevant information for monitoring and debugging purposes

   - Test the API endpoint with various user prompts and edge cases
   - Refine the implementation based on testing results and user feedback

   - Set up a production environment with the necessary dependencies

4. It offers good performance and scalability, ensuring that our API can handle a growing number of requests as the INSPIRE-AI framework gains popularity.

5. Loopback's modular architecture allows for easy integration with other tools and libraries, enabling us to extend the functionality of our API as needed.

In conclusion, Loopback (Strongloop) by IBM is the ideal choice for our use case, as it provides a balance of simplicity, database support, performance, and extensibility. Its features align well with our goal of creating a backend API that incorporates the INSPIRE-AI framework guidance for enhancing user prompts to ChatGPT.

messages.content:
To use Loopback to create an API endpoint that integrates with AI@bloom.pm, you can follow these steps:

1. Install Node.js and Loopback CLI:
   - Download and install Node.js from the official website (https://nodejs.org/)
   - Open a terminal and install the Loopback CLI globally by running `npm install -g @loopback/cli`

2. Create a new Loopback project:
   - In the terminal, navigate to the directory where you want to create your project
   - Run `lb4 app` to start the Loopback application generator
   - Follow the prompts to set up your project (e.g., project name, description, etc.)

3. Create a new Loopback model:
   - In the terminal, navigate to your project directory
   - Run `lb4 model` to create a new model for handling the API requests
   - Define the properties of the model (e.g., prompt, apiKey, response)

4. Create a new Loopback datasource:
   - Run `lb4 datasource` to create a new datasource for your chosen database (e.g., MongoDB, PostgreSQL)
   - Follow the prompts to configure the datasource (e.g., database URL, credentials)

5. Create a new Loopback repository:
   - Run `lb4 repository` to create a new repository for your model
   - Select the datasource you created in the previous step

6. Create a new Loopback controller:
   - Run `lb4 controller` to create a new controller for handling the API endpoint
   - Select the repository you created in the previous step
   - Define the HTTP methods for the endpoint (e.g., POST)

7. Implement the API endpoint logic:
   - Open the controller file created in the previous step
   - Modify the POST method to accept the user prompt and API key from the request body
   - Extract the API key from the request and validate it
   - Use the `@loopback/rest` package to make a POST request to the AI@bloom.pm API, passing the user prompt in the request body
   - Retrieve the response from AI@bloom.pm and return it to the user

8. Configure the API endpoint:
   - Open the `src/application.ts` file
   - Add the necessary import statements for your controller and model
   - Register your controller with the Loopback application

9. Test the API endpoint:
   - Start your Loopback application by running `npm start`
   - Use a tool like Postman or cURL to make a POST request to your API endpoint (e.g., `http://localhost:3000/api/prompt`)
   - Include the user prompt and API key in the request body (e.g., `{ "prompt": "Hello, how are you?", "apiKey": "your_api_key_here" }`)
   - Verify that you receive a response from AI@bloom.pm

10. Deploy your Loopback application:
    - Choose a hosting platform (e.g., Heroku, AWS, DigitalOcean)
    - Follow the platform's deployment instructions for Node.js applications
    - Set the necessary environment variables (e.g., database URL, AI@bloom.pm API key)
    - Start your deployed application and test the API endpoint

Regarding adding the API key to the subject line, it's generally not recommended to include sensitive information like API keys in the URL or subject line of an email. Instead, you should include the API key in the request body or headers of your API request. This helps keep the API key secure and prevents it from being exposed in server logs or browser history.

By following these steps, you can create a Loopback API endpoint that integrates with AI@bloom.pm, allowing users to send prompts and receive responses securely. Remember to handle errors gracefully, validate user input, and protect sensitive information like API keys throughout your implementation.

Quickstart

In this quickstart we'll show you how to:

Get setup with LangChain, LangSmith and LangServe
Use the most basic and common components of LangChain: prompt templates, models, and output parsers
Use LangChain Expression Language, the protocol that LangChain is built on and which facilitates component chaining
Build a simple application with LangChain
Trace your application with LangSmith
Serve your application with LangServe
That's a fair amount to cover! Let's dive in.

Setup

Jupyter Notebook

This guide (and most of the other guides in the documentation) uses Jupyter notebooks and assumes the reader is as well. Jupyter notebooks are perfect for learning how to work with LLM systems because oftentimes things can go wrong (unexpected output, API down, etc) and going through guides in an interactive environment is a great way to better understand them.

You do not NEED to go through the guide in a Jupyter Notebook, but it is recommended. See here for instructions on how to install.

Installation

To install LangChain run:

Pip
Conda
pip install langchain

For more details, see our Installation guide.

LangSmith

Many of the applications you build with LangChain will contain multiple steps with multiple invocations of LLM calls. As these applications get more and more complex, it becomes crucial to be able to inspect what exactly is going on inside your chain or agent. The best way to do this is with LangSmith.

Note that LangSmith is not needed, but it is helpful. If you do want to use LangSmith, after you sign up at the link above, make sure to set your environment variables to start logging traces:

export LANGCHAIN_TRACING_V2="true"
export LANGCHAIN_API_KEY="..."

Building with LangChain

LangChain enables building application that connect external sources of data and computation to LLMs. In this quickstart, we will walk through a few different ways of doing that. We will start with a simple LLM chain, which just relies on information in the prompt template to respond. Next, we will build a retrieval chain, which fetches data from a separate database and passes that into the prompt template. We will then add in chat history, to create a conversation retrieval chain. This allows you to interact in a chat manner with this LLM, so it remembers previous questions. Finally, we will build an agent - which utilizes an LLM to determine whether or not it needs to fetch data to answer questions. We will cover these at a high level, but there are lot of details to all of these! We will link to relevant docs.

LLM Chain

We'll show how to use models available via API, like OpenAI, and local open source models, using integrations like Ollama.

OpenAI
Local (using Ollama)
Anthropic
Cohere
First we'll need to import the LangChain x OpenAI integration package.

pip install langchain-openai

Accessing the API requires an API key, which you can get by creating an account and heading here. Once we have a key we'll want to set it as an environment variable by running:

export OPENAI_API_KEY="..."

We can then initialize the model:

from langchain_openai import ChatOpenAI

llm = ChatOpenAI()

If you'd prefer not to set an environment variable you can pass the key in directly via the api_key named parameter when initiating the OpenAI LLM class:

from langchain_openai import ChatOpenAI

llm = ChatOpenAI(api_key="...")

Once you've installed and initialized the LLM of your choice, we can try using it! Let's ask it what LangSmith is - this is something that wasn't present in the training data so it shouldn't have a very good response.

llm.invoke("how can langsmith help with testing?")

We can also guide its response with a prompt template. Prompt templates convert raw user input to better input to the LLM.

from langchain_core.prompts import ChatPromptTemplate
prompt = ChatPromptTemplate.from_messages([
    ("system", "You are world class technical documentation writer."),
    ("user", "{input}")
])

We can now combine these into a simple LLM chain:

chain = prompt | llm 

We can now invoke it and ask the same question. It still won't know the answer, but it should respond in a more proper tone for a technical writer!

chain.invoke({"input": "how can langsmith help with testing?"})

The output of a ChatModel (and therefore, of this chain) is a message. However, it's often much more convenient to work with strings. Let's add a simple output parser to convert the chat message to a string.

from langchain_core.output_parsers import StrOutputParser

output_parser = StrOutputParser()

We can now add this to the previous chain:

chain = prompt | llm | output_parser

We can now invoke it and ask the same question. The answer will now be a string (rather than a ChatMessage).

chain.invoke({"input": "how can langsmith help with testing?"})

Diving Deeper

We've now successfully set up a basic LLM chain. We only touched on the basics of prompts, models, and output parsers - for a deeper dive into everything mentioned here, see this section of documentation.

Retrieval Chain

To properly answer the original question ("how can langsmith help with testing?"), we need to provide additional context to the LLM. We can do this via retrieval. Retrieval is useful when you have too much data to pass to the LLM directly. You can then use a retriever to fetch only the most relevant pieces and pass those in.

In this process, we will look up relevant documents from a Retriever and then pass them into the prompt. A Retriever can be backed by anything - a SQL table, the internet, etc - but in this instance we will populate a vector store and use that as a retriever. For more information on vectorstores, see this documentation.

First, we need to load the data that we want to index. To do this, we will use the WebBaseLoader. This requires installing BeautifulSoup:

pip install beautifulsoup4

After that, we can import and use WebBaseLoader.

from langchain_community.document_loaders import WebBaseLoader
loader = WebBaseLoader("https://docs.smith.langchain.com/user_guide")

docs = loader.load()

Next, we need to index it into a vectorstore. This requires a few components, namely an embedding model and a vectorstore.

For embedding models, we once again provide examples for accessing via API or by running local models.

OpenAI (API)
Local (using Ollama)
Cohere (API)
Make sure you have the `langchain_openai` package installed an the appropriate environment variables set (these are the same as needed for the LLM).
from langchain_openai import OpenAIEmbeddings

embeddings = OpenAIEmbeddings()

Now, we can use this embedding model to ingest documents into a vectorstore. We will use a simple local vectorstore, FAISS, for simplicity's sake.

First we need to install the required packages for that:

pip install faiss-cpu

Then we can build our index:

from langchain_community.vectorstores import FAISS
from langchain_text_splitters import RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter


text_splitter = RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter()
documents = text_splitter.split_documents(docs)
vector = FAISS.from_documents(documents, embeddings)

Now that we have this data indexed in a vectorstore, we will create a retrieval chain. This chain will take an incoming question, look up relevant documents, then pass those documents along with the original question into an LLM and ask it to answer the original question.

First, let's set up the chain that takes a question and the retrieved documents and generates an answer.

from langchain.chains.combine_documents import create_stuff_documents_chain

prompt = ChatPromptTemplate.from_template("""Answer the following question based only on the provided context:

<context>
{context}
</context>

Question: {input}""")

document_chain = create_stuff_documents_chain(llm, prompt)


If we wanted to, we could run this ourselves by passing in documents directly:

from langchain_core.documents import Document

document_chain.invoke({
    "input": "how can langsmith help with testing?",
    "context": [Document(page_content="langsmith can let you visualize test results")]
})

However, we want the documents to first come from the retriever we just set up. That way, we can use the retriever to dynamically select the most relevant documents and pass those in for a given question.

from langchain.chains import create_retrieval_chain

retriever = vector.as_retriever()
retrieval_chain = create_retrieval_chain(retriever, document_chain)

We can now invoke this chain. This returns a dictionary - the response from the LLM is in the answer key

response = retrieval_chain.invoke({"input": "how can langsmith help with testing?"})
print(response["answer"])

# LangSmith offers several features that can help with testing:...

This answer should be much more accurate!

Diving Deeper

We've now successfully set up a basic retrieval chain. We only touched on the basics of retrieval - for a deeper dive into everything mentioned here, see this section of documentation.

Conversation Retrieval Chain

The chain we've created so far can only answer single questions. One of the main types of LLM applications that people are building are chat bots. So how do we turn this chain into one that can answer follow up questions?

We can still use the create_retrieval_chain function, but we need to change two things:

The retrieval method should now not just work on the most recent input, but rather should take the whole history into account.
The final LLM chain should likewise take the whole history into account
Updating Retrieval

In order to update retrieval, we will create a new chain. This chain will take in the most recent input (input) and the conversation history (chat_history) and use an LLM to generate a search query.

from langchain.chains import create_history_aware_retriever
from langchain_core.prompts import MessagesPlaceholder

# First we need a prompt that we can pass into an LLM to generate this search query

prompt = ChatPromptTemplate.from_messages([
    MessagesPlaceholder(variable_name="chat_history"),
    ("user", "{input}"),
    ("user", "Given the above conversation, generate a search query to look up to get information relevant to the conversation")
])
retriever_chain = create_history_aware_retriever(llm, retriever, prompt)


We can test this out by passing in an instance where the user asks a follow-up question.

from langchain_core.messages import HumanMessage, AIMessage

chat_history = [HumanMessage(content="Can LangSmith help test my LLM applications?"), AIMessage(content="Yes!")]
retriever_chain.invoke({
    "chat_history": chat_history,
    "input": "Tell me how"
})


You should see that this returns documents about testing in LangSmith. This is because the LLM generated a new query, combining the chat history with the follow-up question.

Now that we have this new retriever, we can create a new chain to continue the conversation with these retrieved documents in mind.

prompt = ChatPromptTemplate.from_messages([
    ("system", "Answer the user's questions based on the below context:\n\n{context}"),
    MessagesPlaceholder(variable_name="chat_history"),
    ("user", "{input}"),
])
document_chain = create_stuff_documents_chain(llm, prompt)

retrieval_chain = create_retrieval_chain(retriever_chain, document_chain)

We can now test this out end-to-end:

chat_history = [HumanMessage(content="Can LangSmith help test my LLM applications?"), AIMessage(content="Yes!")]
retrieval_chain.invoke({
    "chat_history": chat_history,
    "input": "Tell me how"
})


We can see that this gives a coherent answer - we've successfully turned our retrieval chain into a chatbot!

Agent

We've so far created examples of chains - where each step is known ahead of time. The final thing we will create is an agent - where the LLM decides what steps to take.

NOTE: for this example we will only show how to create an agent using OpenAI models, as local models are not reliable enough yet.

One of the first things to do when building an agent is to decide what tools it should have access to. For this example, we will give the agent access to two tools:

The retriever we just created. This will let it easily answer questions about LangSmith
A search tool. This will let it easily answer questions that require up-to-date information.
First, let's set up a tool for the retriever we just created:

from langchain.tools.retriever import create_retriever_tool

retriever_tool = create_retriever_tool(
    retriever,
    "langsmith_search",
    "Search for information about LangSmith. For any questions about LangSmith, you must use this tool!",
)


The search tool that we will use is Tavily. This will require an API key (they have generous free tier). After creating it on their platform, you need to set it as an environment variable:

export TAVILY_API_KEY=...

If you do not want to set up an API key, you can skip creating this tool.

from langchain_community.tools.tavily_search import TavilySearchResults

search = TavilySearchResults()

We can now create a list of the tools we want to work with:

tools = [retriever_tool, search]

Now that we have the tools, we can create an agent to use them. We will go over this pretty quickly - for a deeper dive into what exactly is going on, check out the Agent's Getting Started documentation

Install langchain hub first

pip install langchainhub

Install the langchain-openai package To interact with OpenAI we need to use langchain-openai which connects with OpenAI SDK[https://github.com/langchain-ai/langchain/tree/master/libs/partners/openai].

pip install langchain-openai

Now we can use it to get a predefined prompt

from langchain_openai import ChatOpenAI
from langchain import hub
from langchain.agents import create_openai_functions_agent
from langchain.agents import AgentExecutor

# Get the prompt to use - you can modify this!
prompt = hub.pull("hwchase17/openai-functions-agent")

# You need to set OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable or pass it as argument `api_key`.
llm = ChatOpenAI(model="gpt-3.5-turbo", temperature=0)
agent = create_openai_functions_agent(llm, tools, prompt)
agent_executor = AgentExecutor(agent=agent, tools=tools, verbose=True)

We can now invoke the agent and see how it responds! We can ask it questions about LangSmith:

agent_executor.invoke({"input": "how can langsmith help with testing?"})

We can ask it about the weather:

agent_executor.invoke({"input": "what is the weather in SF?"})

We can have conversations with it:

chat_history = [HumanMessage(content="Can LangSmith help test my LLM applications?"), AIMessage(content="Yes!")]
agent_executor.invoke({
    "chat_history": chat_history,
    "input": "Tell me how"
})


Diving Deeper

We've now successfully set up a basic agent. We only touched on the basics of agents - for a deeper dive into everything mentioned here, see this section of documentation.

Serving with LangServe

Now that we've built an application, we need to serve it. That's where LangServe comes in. LangServe helps developers deploy LangChain chains as a REST API. You do not need to use LangServe to use LangChain, but in this guide we'll show how you can deploy your app with LangServe.

While the first part of this guide was intended to be run in a Jupyter Notebook, we will now move out of that. We will be creating a Python file and then interacting with it from the command line.

Install with:

pip install "langserve[all]"

Server

To create a server for our application we'll make a serve.py file. This will contain our logic for serving our application. It consists of three things:

The definition of our chain that we just built above
Our FastAPI app
A definition of a route from which to serve the chain, which is done with langserve.add_routes
#!/usr/bin/env python
from typing import List

from fastapi import FastAPI
from langchain_core.prompts import ChatPromptTemplate
from langchain_openai import ChatOpenAI
from langchain_community.document_loaders import WebBaseLoader
from langchain_openai import OpenAIEmbeddings
from langchain_community.vectorstores import FAISS
from langchain_text_splitters import RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter
from langchain.tools.retriever import create_retriever_tool
from langchain_community.tools.tavily_search import TavilySearchResults
from langchain import hub
from langchain.agents import create_openai_functions_agent
from langchain.agents import AgentExecutor
from langchain.pydantic_v1 import BaseModel, Field
from langchain_core.messages import BaseMessage
from langserve import add_routes

# 1. Load Retriever
loader = WebBaseLoader("https://docs.smith.langchain.com/user_guide")
docs = loader.load()
text_splitter = RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter()
documents = text_splitter.split_documents(docs)
embeddings = OpenAIEmbeddings()
vector = FAISS.from_documents(documents, embeddings)
retriever = vector.as_retriever()

# 2. Create Tools
retriever_tool = create_retriever_tool(
    retriever,
    "langsmith_search",
    "Search for information about LangSmith. For any questions about LangSmith, you must use this tool!",
)
search = TavilySearchResults()
tools = [retriever_tool, search]


# 3. Create Agent
prompt = hub.pull("hwchase17/openai-functions-agent")
llm = ChatOpenAI(model="gpt-3.5-turbo", temperature=0)
agent = create_openai_functions_agent(llm, tools, prompt)
agent_executor = AgentExecutor(agent=agent, tools=tools, verbose=True)


# 4. App definition
app = FastAPI(
  title="LangChain Server",
  version="1.0",
  description="A simple API server using LangChain's Runnable interfaces",
)

# 5. Adding chain route

# We need to add these input/output schemas because the current AgentExecutor
# is lacking in schemas.

class Input(BaseModel):
    input: str
    chat_history: List[BaseMessage] = Field(
        ...,
        extra={"widget": {"type": "chat", "input": "location"}},
    )


class Output(BaseModel):
    output: str

add_routes(
    app,
    agent_executor.with_types(input_type=Input, output_type=Output),
    path="/agent",
)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import uvicorn

    uvicorn.run(app, host="localhost", port=8000)


And that's it! If we execute this file:

python serve.py

we should see our chain being served at localhost:8000.

Playground

Every LangServe service comes with a simple built-in UI for configuring and invoking the application with streaming output and visibility into intermediate steps. Head to http://localhost:8000/agent/playground/ to try it out! Pass in the same question as before - "how can langsmith help with testing?" - and it should respond same as before.

Client

Now let's set up a client for programmatically interacting with our service. We can easily do this with the [langserve.RemoteRunnable](/docs/langserve#client). Using this, we can interact with the served chain as if it were running client-side.

from langserve import RemoteRunnable

remote_chain = RemoteRunnable("http://localhost:8000/agent/")
remote_chain.invoke({
    "input": "how can langsmith help with testing?",
    "chat_history": []  # Providing an empty list as this is the first call
})

To learn more about the many other features of LangServe head here.

Next steps

We've touched on how to build an application with LangChain, how to trace it with LangSmith, and how to serve it with LangServe. There are a lot more features in all three of these than we can cover here. To continue on your journey, we recommend you read the following (in order):

All of these features are backed by LangChain Expression Language (LCEL) - a way to chain these components together. Check out that documentation to better understand how to create custom chains.
Model IO covers more details of prompts, LLMs, and output parsers.
Retrieval covers more details of everything related to retrieval
Agents covers details of everything related to agents
Explore common end-to-end use cases and template applications
Read up on LangSmith, the platform for debugging, testing, monitoring and more
Learn more about serving your applications with LangServe

What is AutoGen

AutoGen is a framework that enables the development of LLM applications using multiple agents that can converse with each other to solve tasks. AutoGen agents are customizable, conversable, and seamlessly allow human participation. They can operate in various modes that employ combinations of LLMs, human inputs, and tools.

AutoGen Overview

AutoGen enables building next-gen LLM applications based on multi-agent conversations with minimal effort. It simplifies the orchestration, automation, and optimization of a complex LLM workflow. It maximizes the performance of LLM models and overcomes their weaknesses.
It supports diverse conversation patterns for complex workflows. With customizable and conversable agents, developers can use AutoGen to build a wide range of conversation patterns concerning conversation autonomy, the number of agents, and agent conversation topology.
It provides a collection of working systems with different complexities. These systems span a wide range of applications from various domains and complexities. This demonstrates how AutoGen can easily support diverse conversation patterns.
AutoGen provides enhanced LLM inference. It offers utilities like API unification and caching, and advanced usage patterns, such as error handling, multi-config inference, context programming, etc.
AutoGen is powered by collaborative research studies from Microsoft, Penn State University, and the University of Washington.

Multi-Agent Conversation Framework

Autogen enables the next-gen LLM applications with a generic multi-agent conversation framework. It offers customizable and conversable agents that integrate LLMs, tools, and humans. By automating chat among multiple capable agents, one can easily make them collectively perform tasks autonomously or with human feedback, including tasks that require using tools via code.

Features of this use case include:

Multi-agent conversations: AutoGen agents can communicate with each other to solve tasks. This allows for more complex and sophisticated applications than would be possible with a single LLM.
Customization: AutoGen agents can be customized to meet the specific needs of an application. This includes the ability to choose the LLMs to use, the types of human input to allow, and the tools to employ.
Human participation: AutoGen seamlessly allows human participation. This means that humans can provide input and feedback to the agents as needed.
For example,

# Load LLM inference endpoints from an env variable or a file

# You can also set config_list directly as a list, for example, config_list = [{'model': 'gpt-4', 'api_key': '<your OpenAI API key here>'},]
assistant = AssistantAgent("assistant", llm_config={"config_list": config_list})
user_proxy = UserProxyAgent("user_proxy", code_execution_config={"work_dir": "coding", "use_docker": False}) # IMPORTANT: set to True to run code in docker, recommended
user_proxy.initiate_chat(assistant, message="Plot a chart of NVDA and TESLA stock price change YTD.")
# This initiates an automated chat between the two agents to solve the task

AutoGen supports different LLM prompting and reasoning strategies, such as ReAct, Reflection/Self-Critique, and more. This notebook demonstrates how to realize general LLM reflection with AutoGen. Reflection is a general prompting strategy which involves having LLMs analyze their own outputs, behaviors, knowledge, or reasoning processes.

This example leverages a generic interface nested chats to implement the reflection using multi-agents.

import autogen

config_list = autogen.config_list_from_json(
    "OAI_CONFIG_LIST",
)
llm_config = {
    "config_list": config_list,  # Assuming you have this defined elsewhere
    "timeout": 120,
}

Construct Agents

Now we create three agents, including user_proxy as a user proxy, writing_assistant for generating solutions (based on the initial request or critique), and reflection_assistant for reflecting and providing critique.

user_proxy = autogen.UserProxyAgent(
    name="user_proxy",
    is_termination_msg=lambda x: x.get("content", "") and x.get("content", "").rstrip().endswith("TERMINATE"),
    human_input_mode="TERMINATE",
    max_consecutive_auto_reply=10,
    code_execution_config={
        # "work_dir": "coding",
        "use_docker": False,
    },  # Please set use_docker=True if docker is available to run the generated code. Using docker is safer than running the generated code directly.
)

writing_assistant = autogen.AssistantAgent(
    name="writing_assistant",
    system_message="You are an writing assistant tasked to write engaging blogpost. You try generate the best blogpost possible for the user's request. If the user provides critique, respond with a revised version of your previous attempts.",
    llm_config=llm_config,
)

reflection_assistant = autogen.AssistantAgent(
    name="reflection_assistant",
    system_message="Generate critique and recommendations on the writing. Provide detailed recommendations, including requests for length, depth, style, etc..",
    llm_config=llm_config,
)


Construct Agent Chats with reflection_assistant being a Nested Agent for Reflection

def reflection_message(recipient, messages, sender, config):
    print("Reflecting...", "yellow")
    return f"Reflect and provide critique on the following writing. \n\n {recipient.chat_messages_for_summary(sender)[-1]['content']}"


nested_chat_queue = [
    {
        "recipient": reflection_assistant,
        "message": reflection_message,
        "max_turns": 1,
    },
]
user_proxy.register_nested_chats(
    nested_chat_queue,
    trigger=writing_assistant,
    # position=4,
)

user_proxy.initiate_chat(
    writing_assistant,
    message="Write an engaging blogpost on the recent updates in AI. The blogpost should be engaging and understandable for general audience. Should have more than 3 paragraphes but no longer than 1000 words.",
    max_turns=2,
)

Let's think through how we can use Langchain, Promptrix, AlphaWave, and AutoGen to create a "Grammarly" for prompting that guides users to prompt for learning using the SCRIBER framework.

Step 1: Understanding the libraries
- Langchain: A library that helps build applications with large language models. It provides modules for prompts, memory, agents, and more.
- Promptrix: A prompt layout engine that breaks prompts into sections and manages token budgets. It supports both text and chat-based prompts.
- AlphaWave: An opinionated client for interfacing with large language models, built on top of Promptrix. It provides features like automatic history management and response repair.
- AutoGen: A framework for building LLM applications using multiple agents that converse with each other to solve tasks. It also provides enhanced LLM inference capabilities.

Step 2: Identifying overlaps and synergies
- Promptrix and AlphaWave have significant overlap, as AlphaWave is built on top of Promptrix. For our use case, we can likely use AlphaWave directly, as it provides a higher-level interface.
- Langchain and AutoGen both provide agent-based functionality. However, Langchain is more general-purpose, while AutoGen is specifically designed for multi-agent conversations. We can potentially use AutoGen for the multi-agent aspect and Langchain for other functionality.

Step 3: Designing the "Grammarly" for prompting
- Use AlphaWave to manage the user's conversation with the AI, including history management and response repair.
- Implement the SCRIBER framework as a set of AutoGen agents that observe the user's prompts and provide guidance:
  - Seek agent: Suggests ways to explore gaps in knowledge
  - Critique agent: Provides constructive criticism on the user's prompts
  - Reflect agent: Encourages the user to reflect on the AI's responses
  - Inquire agent: Prompts the user to ask clarifying questions
  - Broaden/Contract agent: Helps the user expand or narrow the scope of their prompts
  - Explain agent: Asks the AI to explain its reasoning and guides the user to do the same
  - Recurse agent: Encourages the user to think about the prompting process itself
- Use Langchain's memory modules to persist the conversation history and the user's learning progress.
- Integrate the AutoGen agents with AlphaWave, so that they can interrupt the user's conversation with the AI to provide guidance.

Step 4: Implementation plan
1. Set up an AlphaWave client to manage the user's conversation with the AI.
2. Implement the SCRIBER agents using AutoGen, with each agent responsible for a specific aspect of the framework.
3. Integrate the SCRIBER agents with the AlphaWave client, so that they can observe the user's prompts and provide guidance.
4. Use Langchain's memory modules to persist the conversation history and learning progress.
5. Test and refine the system, ensuring that the agents provide helpful and timely guidance without being too disruptive.

In summary, we can use AlphaWave for overall conversation management, AutoGen for implementing the SCRIBER agents, and Langchain for memory persistence and other supporting functionality. By integrating these libraries, we can create a "Grammarly" for prompting that guides users towards more effective learning using the SCRIBER framework.

Get started

LCEL makes it easy to build complex chains from basic components, and supports out of the box functionality such as streaming, parallelism, and logging.

Basic example: prompt + model + output parser

The most basic and common use case is chaining a prompt template and a model together. To see how this works, let‚Äôs create a chain that takes a topic and generates a joke:

%pip install --upgrade --quiet  langchain-core langchain-community langchain-openai

OpenAI
Anthropic
Google
Cohere
FireworksAI
MistralAI
TogetherAI
Install dependencies

pip install -qU langchain-openai

Set environment variables

import getpass
import os

os.environ["OPENAI_API_KEY"] = getpass.getpass()

from langchain_openai import ChatOpenAI

model = ChatOpenAI(model="gpt-4")

from langchain_core.output_parsers import StrOutputParser
from langchain_core.prompts import ChatPromptTemplate

prompt = ChatPromptTemplate.from_template("tell me a short joke about {topic}")
output_parser = StrOutputParser()

chain = prompt | model | output_parser

chain.invoke({"topic": "ice cream"})

"Why don't ice creams ever get invited to parties?\n\nBecause they always drip when things heat up!"


Notice this line of the code, where we piece together these different components into a single chain using LCEL:

chain = prompt | model | output_parser

The | symbol is similar to a unix pipe operator, which chains together the different components, feeding the output from one component as input into the next component.

In this chain the user input is passed to the prompt template, then the prompt template output is passed to the model, then the model output is passed to the output parser. Let‚Äôs take a look at each component individually to really understand what‚Äôs going on.

1. Prompt

prompt is a BasePromptTemplate, which means it takes in a dictionary of template variables and produces a PromptValue. A PromptValue is a wrapper around a completed prompt that can be passed to either an LLM (which takes a string as input) or ChatModel (which takes a sequence of messages as input). It can work with either language model type because it defines logic both for producing BaseMessages and for producing a string.

prompt_value = prompt.invoke({"topic": "ice cream"})
prompt_value

ChatPromptValue(messages=[HumanMessage(content='tell me a short joke about ice cream')])

prompt_value.to_messages()

[HumanMessage(content='tell me a short joke about ice cream')]

prompt_value.to_string()

'Human: tell me a short joke about ice cream'

2. Model

The PromptValue is then passed to model. In this case our model is a ChatModel, meaning it will output a BaseMessage.

message = model.invoke(prompt_value)
message

AIMessage(content="Why don't ice creams ever get invited to parties?\n\nBecause they always bring a melt down!")


If our model was an LLM, it would output a string.

from langchain_openai import OpenAI

llm = OpenAI(model="gpt-3.5-turbo-instruct")
llm.invoke(prompt_value)

'\n\nRobot: Why did the ice cream truck break down? Because it had a meltdown!'

3. Output parser

And lastly we pass our model output to the output_parser, which is a BaseOutputParser meaning it takes either a string or a BaseMessage as input. The specific StrOutputParser simply converts any input into a string.

output_parser.invoke(message)

"Why did the ice cream go to therapy? \n\nBecause it had too many toppings and couldn't find its cone-fidence!"


4. Entire Pipeline

To follow the steps along:

We pass in user input on the desired topic as {"topic": "ice cream"}
The prompt component takes the user input, which is then used to construct a PromptValue after using the topic to construct the prompt.
The model component takes the generated prompt, and passes into the OpenAI LLM model for evaluation. The generated output from the model is a ChatMessage object.
Finally, the output_parser component takes in a ChatMessage, and transforms this into a Python string, which is returned from the invoke method.

input = {"topic": "ice cream"}

prompt.invoke(input)
# > ChatPromptValue(messages=[HumanMessage(content='tell me a short joke about ice cream')])

# > AIMessage(content="Why did the ice cream go to therapy?\nBecause it had too many toppings and couldn't cone-trol itself!")


RAG Search Example

For our next example, we want to run a retrieval-augmented generation chain to add some context when responding to questions.

Set environment variables

import getpass
import os

os.environ["OPENAI_API_KEY"] = getpass.getpass()

from langchain_openai import ChatOpenAI

model = ChatOpenAI(model="gpt-3.5-turbo-0125")

# Requires:
# pip install langchain docarray tiktoken

from langchain_community.vectorstores import DocArrayInMemorySearch
from langchain_core.output_parsers import StrOutputParser
from langchain_core.prompts import ChatPromptTemplate
from langchain_core.runnables import RunnableParallel, RunnablePassthrough
from langchain_openai import OpenAIEmbeddings

vectorstore = DocArrayInMemorySearch.from_texts(
    ["harrison worked at kensho", "bears like to eat honey"],
    embedding=OpenAIEmbeddings(),
)
retriever = vectorstore.as_retriever()

template = """Answer the question based only on the following context:
{context}

Question: {question}
"""
prompt = ChatPromptTemplate.from_template(template)
output_parser = StrOutputParser()

chain.invoke("where did harrison work?")

```python
from langchain.prompts import PromptTemplate
from langchain.llms import OpenAI
from langchain.chains import LLMChain

        self.prompt = PromptTemplate(
            input_variables=["user_prompt"],
            template="Suggest ways to explore gaps in knowledge based on the following user prompt: {user_prompt}"
        )
        self.llm = OpenAI(temperature=0.7)
        self.chain = LLMChain(llm=self.llm, prompt=self.prompt)
    
    def run(self, user_prompt):
        return self.chain.run(user_prompt=user_prompt)

class CritiqueAgent:
    def __init__(self):
        self.prompt = PromptTemplate(
            input_variables=["user_prompt"],
            template="Provide constructive criticism on the following user prompt: {user_prompt}"
        )
        self.llm = OpenAI(temperature=0.7)
        self.chain = LLMChain(llm=self.llm, prompt=self.prompt)
    
    def run(self, user_prompt):
        return self.chain.run(user_prompt=user_prompt)

# ... (other agent classes follow the same pattern)
```

This pseudo code outlines the main loop of the application, where user input is passed to the AlphaWave client to generate an AI response, and then both the user input and AI response are passed to the SCRIBER agents for analysis.
